headline: Santa Maria Grilled Tri-Tip Beef
description: A Santa Maria tri-tip marinade adds incredible flavor to Chef John's recipe for grilled tri-tip beef that's black-on-the-outside, pink-on-the-inside.

video.description: See how to make Santa Maria-style barbecued tri-tip beef.
video.name: Santa Maria Grilled Tri-Tip

name: Santa Maria Grilled Tri-Tip Beef

recipeInstructions.text: Stir salt, black pepper, garlic powder, paprika, onion powder, rosemary, and cayenne pepper together in a bowl.
Place tri-tip in a glass baking dish and coat on all sides with spice mixture. Cover the dish with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 4 hours.
Combine vinegar, vegetable oil, crushed garlic, and Dijon mustard in a sealable container. Cover the container and shake until ingredients are blended.
Remove tri-tip from the refrigerator. Let sit uncovered at room temperature for 30 minutes.
Preheat an outdoor grill for high heat; lightly oil the grates.

Place tri-tip on the preheated grill and brush with vinegar mixture. Cook for 4 minutes, flip, and baste. Flip and baste every 4 minutes until tri-tip starts to firm up and is reddish-pink and juicy in the center, 25 to 30 minutes total. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read 130 degrees F (54 degrees C). Let rest for at least 10 minutes before slicing.

review.reviewBody: Santa Maria Style BBQ is the best cut of beef in the world. It is also a whole meal. The seasoning is very specific - black pepper and garlic salt rub. It is served with salsa, not pesto sauce or orange sauce. It's also served with garlic bread, green salad, and pinquito beans (which are becoming harder to find). The beef must also be cut correctly.
I love this recipe! It is simple and delicious. Thank you for sharing.

Omg I forgot to take photos of the cross section it was just so good! ðŸ¥² I only wish we had leftovers because now everyone in my home is threatening to riot if we donâ€™t have more of this bomb af tri-tip. Wish me luck. (For legal purposes this is a joke but our love for this recipe is not)

The favor of this roast is fantastic, we have made many times. It is better marinated a couple of days. We have shared this recipe with many family members its liked so well. We didn't change a thing.
Excellent flavor and good even when done medium. Due to the cut, remember to slice this across the grain! Good recipe

This was absolutely delicious. Followed directions exactly. Let rub set on meat for about 4 hours and then grilled over a med-light charcoal. The RWV baste was perfect! Yes - you need to watch it because the baste will burn. But a little burn was perfect as it added a nice flavorful crust on the outside, perfectly moist med-rare on inside!

This is my all-time favorite Santa Maria tri-tip recipe! I suggest that cooks try this recipe exactly as directed. Chef John has taken a lot of work out of some of the more involved recipes for this roast. It just really works! I have used this recipe at least twice a month on my 20 year old Weber charcoal grill since Chef John first published this variation. My only suggestion is to use lump charcoal as opposed to briquetts.

I mixed everything into a ziploc bag before reading directions- been cooking 40 years plus- anyway, the mustard,vinegar,oil went in with the spices let it come together for 18 hours first time I made it and 12 the second time. Longer is better. I also prepared it over charcoal just made sure flame was hot but not going to burn the beef, turned it according to Chef John times and it was perfect. Set a timer and donâ€™t leave it because fire can flame up and burn your delicious food. I fried up corn tortillas in peanut oil, chopped cilantro tomatoes seeded, chopped onion it was perfect. I also added the marinade on the meat while it was on the grill each time I turned the beef, with the exception of the last 10 minutes, I didnâ€™t want raw meat juices on my dinner. I donâ€™t care for paprika so used 1/2 smoked paprika and added Chipotle 1/2tsp leaving out cayenne as the first time I made it according to recipe, it was missing a little something, this made a big difference. Enjoy
I made it as per the recipe. It took about 25-30 minutes..and it came out rare in the center.. perfect! We all loved it..a sure keeper ??
5 stars
Excellent way to cook tri tip. Way quicker than I normally bbq it. Thank you for sharing!
Substituted creole spice for the paprika because I didnâ€™t feel like running to the store. I thought it was delicious.
Fabulous recipe! Normally a 2-3 pound tri tip would allow some leftovers for our 4 adult household. Not so with this one.

Absolutely loved this! Followed recipe exactly except did let it sit in the rub for about 8 hours as opposed to only 4. Had some trouble with the marinade causing the gas grill to flame up. Should be corrected by dabbing on instead of pouring. Need to get a meat mop for this. Cooked a 2-lb roast for 20 minutes on high, flipping it 5 times, and it was perfect medium rare! This is a very affordable cut of meat and prepared like this it's every bit as good as a fine, expensive steak!
I loosely followed the recipe and cut back spices to just salt, pepper, and garlic powder. This was the first time I've grilled a tri tip and it came out amazing.

This recipe, while not being exactly true to the style is Fantastic with one exception. Please do not user red wine vinegar! I always use what ever red wine I am drinking that night, or I always keep on hand a box red wine like Bota box to cook with. 

I cannot stress this enough, even using a cheep dry red box wine is better than adding red wine vinegar to the mop sauce, you will not be disappointed.

I -- a not very talented cook -- have now made this 5 times or so. It's not only outstanding, it's easy to make and incredibly tasty as a BBQ tri-tip. Maybe 25 minutes prep with easily accessible ingredients. 

Rub and brush on marinade are terrific. We're major tri-tip fans (California!) and often get Santa Maria style from market. This is better and with a cheaper cut, where you cut away the fat, it's easily better than marinade TT you get in store.

Make sure you pull Tri Tip off grill at about 120 - 123 F. After about 115 temp rises rapidly after that so keep an eye on it. No more than 2.5 minutes at that point.

I did a 3.2 pound piece, adding only parsley to the rub, and everyone thought it was fantastic. The spices are great for beef. My roast had a thick fat layer on one side which we left on top and it made a crispy flavorful crust. However it was pouring rain n this day, so we switched to the oven roasted version Chef John has on here, and skipped the basting sauce. It was just wonderful and we canâ€™t wait to try it again on the grill with the sauce. We will be using this rub for other beef, too!
Yummy!
Super good, and oh so worth the frequent basting!

We thoroughly enjoyed the recipe, didn't change a thing. But I need a better grill so I can raise and or lower the coals so the meat doesn't go up in flames when I flip it. However, it did make a nice bark. We will be making this again soon.
Made it exactly as directed except used yellow mustard powder instead of Dijon mustard since thatâ€™s all I had. We have never had such a juicy tender try tip EVER! I was so impressed.?

We raise our own beef but had never had the tri-tip cut until it was included in one of our processed steers. Tried this recipe today and it was amazing! We didnâ€™t change a thing and actually cooked it in our grill during a snowstorm. Weâ€™re super excited to have it again at our lake house this summer!
Excellent. Will make again. The grilling instructions were spot on!

Really good for beginner grillers! I left the rub on longer than 4 hours - more like 8 hours. Delicious and moist. Donâ€™t over cook it. Saving to make this again. And saved the extra rub ingredients for other meat.
Made this recipe exactly as written, and it was excellent. Thank you Chef John. Another great meal with your help.

First time making Tri-Tip and wanted to try it Santa Maria Style at the recommendation of a friend (Thanks Cathy Myers!). This recipe was so outstanding good that tri-tip is now one of our favorite cuts of beef. The only change I made was that I cut the amount of salt by half (watching our sodium content). My husband seared it as directed in the video, but finished cooking it indirectly thereafter. Topped it with a cherry tomato relish. I made this tonight for dinner and it was DELICIOUS! The 5 of us ate the entire tri tip served with creamy mac and cheese, broccoli, and salad. I will definitely use this method again! Thank you Chef John!
Absolutely loved this. Cooked on my Cobb grill and served it on homemade Kaiser rolls. Outstanding.

The key to me for this recipe is the oil, vinegar, garlic, and mustard marinade that you brush on while grilling. I generally use a simpler rub (garlic powder, salt, parsley) and then finish with this marinade.
Incredible! A keeper! Amazing!
Incredible! A keeper! Amazing!
Really, really good! Thanks Chef John!
This is a great recipe with a lot of flavor! I love the addition of the red wine/oil/garlic mixture while cooking it.
This is a great Grilling recipe. Not to be confused with bbq.

Threw all the ingredients in a glass baking dish, mixed them up and put the tri tip in for 24 hours. Turned it over in the morning. Delicious! My kiddo who only likes the costco marinade asked for seconds :)

This is the 3rd time I have made this! The first time I finished it in a such oven over coals. The 2nd time I finished it in the oven, the 3rd time was in the smoker. I have to say the first time in the Dutch oven was the best! Cooked to medium rare all 3 times!

It's from Chef John, so it has to be excellent. I am a Central Coaster, so IMHO, it should be titled "Chef John's Tri-Tip". 
Santa Maria style tri-tip is basic seasonings, cooked over an open spit/grill burning oak, served with salad, charro beans and garlic sourdough bread.

I've made this recipe a couple times with different steak cuts (tri tip, top sirloin, prime rib). It really is good, but DW complains it a little spicy. Ice not modified it at all for any cut and it is one of my favorite. DW says her favorite is the tri tip. I like them all.
Thank you Chef John! Another fantastic recipe.
THE easiest and best tri-tip I've ever made. Will definitely make this again!

This was an unbelievable good recipe, as all of Chef Johns recipes. It is -30 Celsius here so seared it in cast iron and finished it in the oven till 135 internal. Made Philly cheesesteak sandwiches out of it. Amazing.

This roast was amazing. I was concerned that it would be too tough since my roast was about a pound larger than what the recipe called for. It came out great. I cooked it on a gas grill at about 500*F for about 30 minutes turning and basting just like the recipe called for. I will definitely cook it again. it was incredibly juicy and had a range if levels from medium well at the edges to medium rare in the center.
This recipe worked out really well - pretty easy to make, and everyone loved the flavor. Definitely will make again in the future : )
Doubled the recipe for extra coverage. Great flavor!
This was so so good!
Love the marinade. I smoked it based on weight. 1/2 hour per pound at 215. Came out phenomenally.

Crusty outside, tender, juicy inside. Perfect! Did not leave on the grill as long as stated in recipe. Checked temp at 20 minutes, roast was already above recommended temp. It was a hot fire! Pulled and let rest - fantastic. Served with garlic mashed potatoes and steamed broccoli.

Excellent recipe. I only had about 3 hours for it to sit with the rub on it and that was plenty of time for great flavor. I used smoked paprika instead of paprika, so it had a smoky flavor even though cooked on a gas grill.

Beautiful wet/dry ingredients. I did use smoked paprika, fresh rosemary chopped. Only difference will be turning grill heat down a bit, up the time. It was too raw in the center. I don't have a thermometer. Otherwise, a definite keeper. Thanks (again), Chef John!

I didn't "love" the flavor of the rub/baste combo. It was fine but just fine. I will not use this recipe again. 

I truly appreciate the folk(s) who took the time to upload everything, thank you (all) just wasn't thrilled by the flavor.
Easy and enjoyable recipe to make.
We love this recipe just as is. The flavors are so good and we rarely have any leftovers. This is my go to tri-tip recipe!!â€™n
It was good and easy to make but super salty. If I make it again, I will probably omit the salt.

I made this with a 2.8 lb tri-tip roast. It was good but not amazing as I was hoping. A couple things fell short for me flavor-wise, and it wasn't as easy to grill as it appeared to be in the video. I'm going to try it a few more times though. 

The amount of rub just barely covered the roast. If I make it again I would double all of the ingredients except the salt. You will end up with more than you need but you can just toss the extra.

Grilling was tougher than expected. The juice from the roast and the basting sauce continually fell into the fire causing the flame to rise. The roast caught on fire several times. So I had to move it over to the other side of the grill, wait for the flame to go down, then move it back over. I understand the video shows a high flame, but if I kept the roast in that high of a flame for whole time it would have been charcoal on the outside.

It took 35-40 min to cook. That could be because it was 0.3 lbs more and/or because I had to keep moving it aside. I definitely recommend using a meat thermometer. You won't be able to tell when it is done from looking at the exterior or by the amt of cooking time. 

In the end, the roast was flavorful. The ends were well done and the middle was medium, just like the video. The outside was crispy and tasty. Though next time I would double the ingredients except for the salt.

One small modification was that I replaced paprika with chili powder because of a food allergy.
Made this last week, and it was perfect! Super simple, and incredibly tasty!
Excellent as usual, Chef John!

Always a winner! I follow the recipe exactly. Our guests always rave about how delicious this tri-tip is. Many of these folks have never had tri-tip so we or they donâ€™t give a rip what the Santa Maria purists think! On that note - Iâ€™ve had tri-tip in California and it is great. This is altogether a different outcome but it is none the less awesome. Give it a try!

This SM Grilled Tri-Tip Beef was incredible. We BBQ'd it and the only complaint I had was we should have taken it off the BBQ sooner. But even with that we couldn't get enough of it. I loved the rub and the marinade was also delicious. I can hardly wait to do this again but take it off the BBQ sooner. Turn the meat 4-5 times only if you like it Medium Rare. Thank you Chef John, another wonderful recipe.

Then went belly up w/o silicone valley investors. Evernote/OneNote and recipe software apps like AR/BO nicely format recipes, though. So glad it's here on AR!
This is DELICIOUS! The part I have to remember is to start the rub and get the meat up to room temperature before it's time to start cooking it on the grill. The mix of spices just get into the meat and it's so darn good. 
It's amazing when I follow the directions. Better than any restaurant! Yummy!!!! I've used this for years, now!
Made this tonight and everybody loved it. Tender, moist and full of flavor. I will definitely make this again.
This was great. We used fresh rosemary but did everything else the same. Canâ€™t wait to make it again.
Followed the recipe exactly aside from smoking with pecan wood on my Webber grill. Un-freaking-believable. Canâ€™t recommend this recipe enough. It WILL change your life.

I've made this once before for my brother in law. We bother really liked it. I served it with mashed potatoes and asparagus. I followed the recipe and it came out tender and juicy, perfectly cooked inside with crust on the outside. I'm making this again this weekend. I've coated the meat this time with olive oil, then applied the rub. This will sit for 24 hours in the fridge. I'll repost how this one comes out. Tri Tip is not readily available here in north Texas, but Market Street carries it at $7.99 per pound. Good quality as well.
Was delicious and will be making again! Thank you for the recipe!
Fabulous
Great flavor. Easy to follow instructions resulted in one of My favorite recipes.

First time grilling a tri tip! Worked out great didnâ€™t use the cayenne pepper and only used 2 garlic cloves in the bast. Let it sit for about 20 hours in the fridge with the seasoning. When flipping every 4 mins I rotated just a tad. I had a water gun ready for flare ups. Grill heat was high till 8 mins then med high for another 24. Came out med well juicey and perfect for my family tastes. Didnâ€™t cut into till after a 10 min rest. Served with grilled potatoes, grilled zucchini and maple baked beans.

This was amazing! We cooked it a little longer (to 145) because my husband likes his medium well, but there were still some medium rare slices after letting it rest for 15-20 minutes. Juicy and delicious! And not too salty - though I didn't follow the recipe exactly for the rub - I didn't have some ingredients, but I had a Trader Joe's Seasoning Salt that had most, plus a few extras, and I added rosemary, sage, dill, and a little extra salt - actually, I think that was the rub from the Oregon herb tri-tip rub recipe I found on here, but whatever - it was delicious! I didn't have red wine vinegar for the basting, so I added a little red wine to the white wine vinegar mixture. And we ran out of propane during pre-heating and didn't notice until we put the tri tip on the grill - we changed, put it up to high, and didn't baste until the 3rd flip when it was up to temp, and it still turned out great!

Next time we're making this for guests and serving Margaritas with it!
Loved it. I made mine inside of foil on the bbq grill.. I would recommend doubling the baste for 2.5lbs

Great recipe! I used a 3.0 lb cut and trimmed the excess fat. It is very difficult to keep it over a hot direct fire for so long (I cooked it 24 total minutes, 4 minutes a side basting every turn) if you're like me and usually cook a ribeye but my oh my it sure was worth it. I let it rest a full 20 minutes after I pulled it from the grill tented in aluminum foil and it was worth the wait. 

Don't forget to cut across the grain! I ended up cutting mine into two pieces because the grains on my cut changed direction. 

P.S. if you're hesitant to use rosemary because it isn't a favorite spice like me just go for it! The rosemary flavor is very subtle and pairs perfectly with the red wine vinegar baste!

This was amazing. And yes I have had tri tip in Santa Maria, and yes I know this isnâ€™t smoked. But this is just a deliciously wonderful recipe (as usual Chef John!!) I allowed the rubber meat to rest in the fridge 24 hrs. And I made my basting sauce with golden balsamic since I didnâ€™t have any red wine vinegar. It turned out amazing. Thank you for yet another winner recipe Chef John.
Amazing - new family favorite

Oh my gosh!!! This recipe was amazing! I followed the instructions, except that I used my own dry rub mix. I didn't refrigerate the meat for 4 hours, but did let it sit at room temperature for 30 minutes with the dry rub on it. The garlic-vinegar mixture added so much flavor to the meat. It was surprisingly juicy and tender. Grilling took about 25 minutes to achieve a nice dark exterior, and medium rare inside.
Outstanding recipe. My wife and kids loved it. Don't change a thing.
I went for the more simplistic route, as in no cayenne pepper or paprika but it was delicious and beautiful. It was raining so I made it on my stovetop grill pan instead of my outside grill.

My family loved it. I had a large tri tip planned on making tacos tomorrow. Not a chance it was gone. I did one slight change. I added cayenne pepper I used just under a teaspoon It was not spicey at all next time I may add 1/4 more cayenne pepper. Even my 3 year old granddaughter ate it up. 

I was so unsure of the vinegar mix. I just wanted to follow the recipe, so I actually made a special trip to buy apple cider vinegar. When I returned I looked up recipe... UGH Red wine. Lucky I had it on hand..

Thank you Chef John love your videos. I doubt you read these reviews. Do you make new viedos on a regular if so how do we sign up to receive notifications?
Awesome!! Highly recommend it!!!
Followed this exactly and we loved it. We will surely make again and again.

I have made this several times now following the listed ingredients and cooking instructions. 5 stars with a ton of reviews is exactly what this recipe is. Awesome and a must try for every meat lover out there.
I made this recipe many times with prawns I call it poor man's surf and turf

Great history behind this recipe.

Cook as instructed and make sure you don't let the heat get away from you on the grill (it is all to easy to do with propane). You can EASILY up the spices if you want a little more flavor, but don't skimp on the basting each time you turn it over and do that at least as frequently as they advise.

This might have been good had my husband not killed it on the BBQ. The flavor was good, the crust was good, but he choose to cook it for the full 30 minutes and it was over done, not what I was going for, but perfect for him (I wonder if that was his plan all along?). I will use this rub again, but use a meat thermometer, 20minutes would have been better for our tri-tip.

I made this recipe the first time exactly as stated and it was awesome! The second time I accidentally reversed the marinate with the rub:) So I marinated in the vinegar mixture and then added the rub and it was also amazing. You can't go wrong with this.

I made this recipe the first time exactly as stated and it was awesome! The second time I accidentally reversed the marinate with the rub:) So I marinated in the vinegar mixture and then added the rub and it was also amazing. You can't go wrong with this.

We followed this recipe to the T, it turned out perfect. This was our first Beef Tri-Tip, 1.9 lb the flavor was out of this world. A little kick, just enough everyone loved it. Had leftovers the next day, planning to cook again. Leftovers would be great in a salad for lunch.
This is a great recipe and easy to make. The finished product is reminiscent of prime rib. I usually don't get this cut of meat, but I will not shy away from buying it in the future.
Wow! What a delicious dish this turnout out to be. The hardest part was trying not to eat it all while I was carving it up. Will make again.
I would not change anything it was perfect it had a lovely char to the meat and nice and juicey

Chef, your recipes are always good and dependable. I have begun to rely on them for new items that I am trying. But it's a little hard to follow your cadence some time. I'm listening on a laptop with small speakers. The tri tip recipe was perfect. I was afraid it would be tough and we like extra rare meat. But tri tip has to be cooked so I followed the temp. setting and it was fine

I have bever made a tritip and this recipe walked me through it perfectly. Very tender and very delicious.
